comments.commentBody: An editorial overflowing with facts, accompanied by a sparkling clean comment page free of the usual baseless right-wing retorts? It's utterly pastoral. How long can it possibly last?
Oh, I thought this was about 2010. And, from my perch in the northwestern U.S., I was about to say, "Bring it on."

Barack Obama won the Nobel Peace Prize (is there an equivalent to Baseball-Reference.com for truly sizing up the peacemaking skills of a politician?), so should this little award going to Derek Jeter really upset anyone?

I think Jon Miller is the best ever at baseball on the radio, and I go back to the mid-1950s listening to a Pacific Coast League legend in Seattle named Leo Lassen. Miller is on every piece of the action, stays right with the ball and strike counts, and adds anecdotes in just the proper amounts as a game moves along. While I have no complaints with his tv work, he may be better suited for radio, and if so that's terrific by me. Compare Miller to other radio broadcasters and you'll quickly see that many are just phoning it in. As for Morgan, I've wonder how he lasted as long as he did. The guy seemed to carry a sense of entitlement into the booth, that old "you never played the game" schtick, and had a tendency to put Miller down from time to time from that perspective. I never heard Morgan say anything that could charitably called insightful. I hope Miller takes the radio-only deal. That way I can listen to him on ESPN on Sundays, XM radio when the Giants are at home, and on mlb.com gameday when they're on the road. I might be the biggest Jon Miller fan out here.
Now will retire my mute button.
one of my best baseball memories is sitting in my car, not wanting to miss anything on the way into my home, listening to Niehaus call a Blyleven gem.
Requiescat in Pace.

Thank you for such a wonderful piece, and acknowledging our amazing broadcaster. I can't even imagine what a game will be like without hearing his calls, his corny rye bread and mustard. Indeed.

I was at the Kingdome when we just rattled around in there, when the Mariners were so bad. I was there during the Junior and Randy Johnson era, when they were so good. I took my son when he was a toddler, and as he grew up. We went to games at Safeco field, when we won 116 games, and back to being abysmal again.

Through it all, Dave has been our constant.
Thanks, Dave!!!
Fly, Fly away!!!

Why is everybody down on Joe Morgan? Critics should be thankful they did not have to listen to Dave O'Brien and Rick Sutcliffe every Sunday night. Both should attend classes in remedial English; i.e., "rout" instead of route, "off of" instead of off and any player "that" instead of who. Or it could be even worse with a team of Michael Kay and Gary Cohen who constantly criticize opposing teams,their fans and stadia.Both ragged on Bonds incessantly in 2007. But when Roger Clemens returned every half season after spending the first half juicing in retirement, Kay praised him as a "freak of nature." When Kirk Radomski was caught red-handed distributing peds in the Mets' clubhouse, Cohen suddenly had nothing to say.
I almost dropped my lap top rotating it around to visualize the answers! Well done Mr. Zhou. I knew something was up with all the "Z"s I had entered into the puzzle.

G'day IT IS I!

I agree with Alan !MOM!
So that explains all the "Z"s - I was thinking Mr. Zhou just was partial to that letter.

Jim says (very aptly) that Thursdays are our Scherzos of the week. But this one was also a Fugue. [Afternote: ah!! I just read your response Andrew, you are saying the same thing! : )]
This was just brilliant! and then to have TURNTURNTURN across the middle - I am gobsmacked!

Nearly transgressed the NYTimes Breakfast Rule in trying multiple times to spell SHIHTZU but ASSIZE kindly saved me (wipes brow).

It was MOONMISSION I mean SNOISSIWNOOW that got me going - so clever! - I do love Thursdays hehe
This was SO out of the box...what an absolute treat! Thanks for the wonderful fun!
Can't wait to read everyone's comments now....(sorry for all the superlatives, I was really taken with this one!)

I consider the iPad little more than a toy -- an interesting one, no doubt, useful for consuming media. But it's all-but incapable of creating any, or much of anything.

I think Tablet PC's got a bad rap. I own no fewer than five Motioncomputing LE 1700s (a model no longer available, superseded by the J3500

http://www.motioncomputing.com...

and I can't live without 'em -- my right arms.

Why five? Each is configured to perform a grouped task, like tax/accounting, or design/critical thinking, or administration/strategic planning -- that sort of thing. I use as many as three at once because the work flows logically between the groups. If I could network them and operate them from a central core computer I'd do it that way, but restrictive EULAs (End User Licensing Agreements) interfere with an otherwise sensible arrangement.

Like all things, Tablet PCs have shortcomings. My main gripe doesn't involve the hardware so much as how Microsoft's Windows Vista Business OS runs on it. Vista turns out to be a bit of a disappointment. Supposedly, intramural corporate politics at Microsoft created Win-Vista's shortcomings. One department wouldn't cooperate with another so the OS that Microsoft finally released isn't versatile enough. The teams that developed Vista didn't go far enough in integrating the stylus handwriting functions with various applications; why Tablet PCs haven't caught on with the general market. Leo Laporte (http://techguylabs.com/) can probably shed some light on the ins-&-outs of how this came about.

Supposedly, Nuance Software's Dragon Naturally speaking (speech-to-text) application (http://www.nuance.com/dragon/index.htm) surmounts this bottleneck, although I haven't tested it myself. I think with my fingers; dictating, I lose the thread. When I start talking, my brain stops working (funny thing about that) unless I read from a prepared outline supplemented by detailed notes, complicating the process considerably.

However, even with the drawbacks and shortcomings I find the Tablet PC platform remarkably versatile. The most useful application? For thinking (conceptualizing, designing, or plain ordinary critical thinking) I rely on Mindmanager 9.157

http://www.mindjet.com/

I'm one of the data points referred to in this article.  I'm extremely happy with my Droid X.  I read books on its Kindle reader and with the Google Navigator that comes installed I never have to stop to ask for directions (not that I would anyway, since I'm male :-)
You sir have no idea what fun is.

Wow, nearly half a BILLION phones in ONE quarter? That's amazing. And, Apple has finally surpassed RIM, making it the single largest smartphone seller and selling more than half as many phones as ALL the Android manufacturers combined. I think we're seeing a convergence of the old and new here. The old names, like Nokia and RIM, are slowly losing ground, while the new order rises with Apple and Google at the lead. It's been coming on for a while now, but we're finally seeing the results of the smartphone conquest.

I have the iPhone 4 and love it. I'm a heavy user, and deeply in love with my device. However, since AT&T is so terrible at getting me a 3G signal, or better yet, unable to get me a 3G signal; I had to get a contract with Verizon and get their MiFi so I can actually use my iPhone.

Long story short, I need Verizon so I can use my AT&T iPhone. How sad is that?
I tried it but...seems pointless.  I guess it keeps me from going to ugly pages, but that's only useful if I'm judging a web site by its cover.
coakl:  It's a game!

As a professional wedding/lifestyle photographer Mr. Nielsen says it best with the line, “Invest in good photo shoots: a great photographer can add a fortune to your Web site’s business value.”

Funny that some people will need to read studies, reports and analysis to understand/realize what most full-time professional photographers, art patrons and enthusiasts have been saying for decades.

That said, I think its wonderful that technology is empowering these people to more clearly explain these beliefs/values via the scientific method.
Oly=Olympia beer, I think...

I smoked for nearly 20 years before finally being able to quit about a year ago. It took me 7-8 tries over as many years. Even now, if I have one puff, I know I am hooked for another 8 years.

I fully agree with these labels, we should have had these many many years ago.
So what's the story between Convey and Bradley? It would be extremely disappointing if he weren't called up: it's a friendly, after all, and it's not like we have a ton of options at left back.
Pelosi's arrogance was exemplified by "We have to pass the bill so you can find out what's in it." Pelosi was elected to serve the people, not to serve as queen.

Maintaining 2 billion Chinese on your side will become the Chinese government's pandora's box in the near future, and the rest of the world would do well to remember the pressures that drove Japan's expansionist moves in 1938.

It does not take long from boom to bust when the right (or rather wrong) markers go against you.

If you don't get the purity ring, you shouldn't get to make all the decisions. Michelle should be in a leadership position. She represents that zany new wave that is the mandate from the last election. Drill Baby Drill.
